current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text: To amend the Public Health Service Act with regard to research on asthma, and for other purposes.

committee-name.#text: Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the

text.#text:
This Act may be cited as
			 the
Congress finds the following:

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, in 2012 more than
			 25,500,000
			 Americans had been diagnosed with asthma, including an estimated 6,800,000
			 children.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

text.#text:
The number of
			 people ever diagnosed with asthma increased by 50 percent between 1998 and
			 2012.
			 According to
			 the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, in 2010 more than 3,400
			 Americans
			 died from asthma. The rate of mortality from asthma is higher among
			 African-Americans and women.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

text.#text: According to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
report that asthma accounted for
			 approximately 480,000
			 hospitalizations and 2,100,000 visits to hospital emergency
			 departments
			 in 2009.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Centers for
			 Disease Control and Prevention

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, the annual cost of asthma to
			 the
			 United States is approximately $56,000,000,000, including $5,900,000,000
			 in
			 indirect costs from lost productivity.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

text.#text: According to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, 10,500,000 school days and
			 14,200,000 work days are missed annually as a result of asthma.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

text.#text: According to the

Asthma episodes
			 can be triggered by both outdoor air pollution and indoor air pollution,
			 including pollutants such as cigarette smoke and combustion by-products.
			 Asthma
			 episodes can also be triggered by indoor allergens such as animal dander
			 and
			 outdoor allergens such as pollen and molds.

Public health
			 interventions and medical care in accordance with existing guidelines have
			 been
			 proven effective in the treatment and management of asthma. Better asthma
			 management could reduce the numbers of emergency department visits and
			 hospitalizations due to asthma. Studies published in medical journals have
			 shown that better asthma management results in improved asthma outcomes at
			 a
			 lower cost.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
reported that less than half of
			 people with asthma had been taught how to avoid asthma triggers. More
			 education
			 about triggers, proper treatment, and asthma management methods is
			 needed.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

text.#text: In 2011, the

The alarming rise
			 in the prevalence of asthma, its adverse effect on school attendance and
			 productivity, and its cost for hospitalizations and emergency room visits,
			 highlight the importance of public health interventions, including
			 increasing
			 awareness of asthma as a chronic illness, its symptoms, the role of both
			 indoor
			 and outdoor environmental factors that exacerbate the disease, and other
			 factors that affect its exacerbations and severity. The goals of the
			 Federal
			 Government and its partners in the nonprofit and private sectors should
			 include
			 reducing the number and severity of asthma attacks, asthma's financial
			 burden,
			 and the health disparities associated with asthma.

conduct asthma

compile and

compile and

				department visits by adults associated with asthma nationally and
			 in each State

				as well as lifetime and current prevalence.
